selected_quotes: Parents of children playing recreational football continue to hold misconceptions about many aspects of concussion.
94% of surveyed parents believed that their child had never had a #concussion
Results of voluntary survey observing #concussion knowledge of parents of youth tackle #football players
No parent was able to classify all symptoms listed as correctly related or not related to #concussion.

citation.abstract: Sports-related concussion among professional, collegiate, and, more recently, high school athletes has received much attention from the media and medical community. To our knowledge, there is a paucity of research regarding parental knowledge of sports-related concussion. The aim of this study was to evaluate parental knowledge of concussion in young children who participated in recreational tackle football.
citation.journal: Journal of Trauma and Acute Care Surgery, The
citation.title: Knowledge assessment of sports-related concussion among parents of children aged 5 years to 15 years enrolled in recreational tackle football

news.title: CDC to Back New Research on Sports Concussion Prevention
news.summary: CDC revealed new plans to address concussions in youth sports Tuesday, with an announcement that it will commit $3.3 million to study ways to prevent brain injuries.

news.title: Heads Up: Has CDC Concussion Awareness Program Flopped?
news.summary: This is the first in a series of exclusive MedPage Today reports focusing on Heads Up, the CDC's concussion awareness and prevention program.
